title: 110_s3486
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission on Measures of Household Economic Security Act of 2008". Congress recognizes the importance of Federal economic statistics for policymakers and legislators to assess the well-being of American individuals and households. Questions have been raised about the accuracy of existing economic measures in reflecting this well-being. The importance of accurate economic statistics for assessing the well-being of American individuals and households is recognized by Congress. Commonly reported economic indicators like GDP, unemployment rate, and consumer price indices may not accurately reflect the economic status of average Americans. A more comprehensive assessment and regular reporting of economic well-being would help governments track and address concerns relevant to American households more effectively. Establishment of Commission on Measures of Household Economic Security. The Commission on Measures of Household Economic Security is established with 8 members appointed by Senate leaders in consultation with various committees. The Commission on Measures of Household Economic Security is established with 8 members appointed by Senate leaders, the Speaker of the House, and the minority leader of the House, in consultation with relevant committees. The Commission on Measures of Household Economic Security is established with 8 members appointed by Senate leaders, the Speaker of the House, and the minority leader of the House, in consultation with relevant committees. The chairmen and ranking members of the committees referred to in subparagraph (C) shall appoint members, one of whom must be an employee of the Federal Reserve. Members must be appointed on a nonpartisan basis and be academic or government policy experts in economics, statistics, or related fields. Members must be appointed within 60 days of the enactment of the Act and serve for the life of the Commission. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission shall select a Chairman and Vice Chairman from among its members. Meetings must be held within 60 days of all members being appointed, and regularly every 3 months. A majority of members constitute a quorum, and the Commission may establish rules by majority vote for conducting business. The Commission must establish rules for conducting business in accordance with the Act and other applicable laws. The Commission is responsible for establishing rules in compliance with the Act and other laws. The Commission will identify, study, and evaluate existing economic statistics and data to improve measures for assessing the economic well-being of American households. This includes recommending new standards and methodologies for measuring economic well-being. The Commission will develop statistical measures to describe the current debt situation of American individuals and households, including categories of debt like credit card debt, education loans, and mortgage payments. They will also analyze the movement of Americans between salaried jobs with benefits to wage jobs with limited benefits, comparing income with the value of benefits programs like health insurance and retirement plans. Additionally, they will assess the percentage of Americans covered by employer-provided benefits. The Commission will analyze the extent of health care coverage and savings rates, income distribution disparities, government transfer payments, and household breakdown statistics. The study will analyze household expenditures on categories like food, shelter, medical expenses, debt servicing, and energy. It will also focus on nonmarket satellite accounts related to household production, education investments, health investments, non-profit/volunteer sectors, and environmental assets/services. The Commission conducting the study will consult with various government leaders, citizen groups, and experts, including the Chairman of the Federal Reserve, Secretaries of Commerce, Labor, and Treasury, as well as other key officials and representative citizen groups. The Commission will consult with government leaders, citizen groups, and experts. Representative citizen groups will be selected to reflect national diversity. The Commission will submit a report to Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and economic statistics reporting. The Commission will assess the uses, benefits, costs, logistics, and reliability of producing economic statistics. It will also consider the need for a standing commission to address household economic information, non-market satellite accounts, and other economic indicators. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission has the authority to conduct hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and utilize postal services as needed to carry out its duties under this Act. The Commission has the authority to use postal services and enter into contracts with various entities for conducting activities necessary for its duties. The contracts cannot extend beyond the termination date of the Commission. SEC. 6. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission may be compensated at a daily rate equal to the maximum annual pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees on the Commission serve without additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, are allowed for Commission members. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The Chairman can also determine their compensation without adhering to specific regulations. The Chairman of the Commission can appoint an executive director and personnel without following civil service laws. The executive director and employees will be federal employees under specific sections of the United States Code. Members of the Commission are not included in this classification. The Commission can appoint federal government employees without reimbursement, maintain their civil service status, and procure temporary services as needed. Additionally, volunteers can serve without compensation and be reimbursed for local travel. Volunteers serving the Commission can be reimbursed for local travel, office supplies, and other travel expenses. They are considered federal government employees for purposes of compensation, conflicts of interest, and tort claims. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services to the Commission upon request, on a reimbursable basis. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting the report. $2,500,000 from the Bureau of Labor Statistics for fiscal year 2009 will be allocated to the Commission's activities until its termination.
